translated: Here, what is the meaning of faculty?
The most excellent, sovereign, and radiant are called faculties, and by this they collectively form the meaning of faculty predominance.
To whom does this meaning of predominance belong?
Verse:
It is said that the five [faculties] are predominant in four [matters], and the four [faculties] are predominant in two kinds.
The five [faculties] and the eight [faculties] are each predominant in the defiled and pure [paths].
Commentary:
The five faculties such as the eye are each predominant in four matters:
1. Adorning the body, 2. Nourishing the body, 3. Producing consciousness, etc., 4. Unique functions.
First, as for the eye and ear faculties adorning the body, it means that if one is blind or deaf, the body is ugly.
As for nourishing the body, it means that by seeing and hearing, one avoids danger and difficulty.
As for producing consciousness, etc., it means giving rise to the two consciousnesses and their associated [mental factors].
The unique activity of the nose, tongue, and body is to smell, taste, and touch, respectively.
The nose, tongue, and body beautify the person, just as the eyes and ears do.
They nourish the person, because they enjoy material food.
They generate consciousness, because they generate the three consciousnesses and their associates.
The unique activity of the nose, tongue, and body is to smell, taste, and touch, respectively.ğŸ”½The female, male, life, and mind faculties each have two kinds of dominant influence.
The two dominant influences of the female and male faculties are the distinction of sentient beings and the distinction of characteristics.
The distinction of sentient beings means that these two faculties cause sentient beings to be classified as female and male.
The distinction of characteristics means that these two faculties cause differences in physical form, voice, breasts, etc.
Some say:
These two faculties have dominant influence over two things, because they increase in passion and purity.
Why is this?
The nature of these two faculties is damaged.

Eunuchs, neuters, and hermaphrodites do not have undiscipline, nor do they have the various defiled dharmas of cutting off good roots, nor do they have discipline, nor do they have the pure dharmas of attaining fruits and detaching from the defilements.
The two functions of the faculty of life are: it can continue the continuity of the aggregates, and it can maintain the continuity of the aggregates.
The two functions of the faculty of thought are: it can continue rebirth, and it can freely follow.
As for continuing rebirth, a scripture says:
At that time, gandharvas have two minds, either associated with craving or associated with aversion, and so on.
As for freely following, a scripture says:
The mind guides the world, the mind pervades all,
In this way, the mind, a single dharma, freely follows all.ğŸ”½The five faculties such as pleasure and the eight faculties such as faith have dominance in defilement and purity, respectively.
As for the five faculties such as pleasure having dominance in defilement, the latent afflictions increase accordingly.
The eight faculties of faith, etc., are dominant in purification, because the pure dharmas grow by relying on them.
Other masters say that
the five of pleasure, etc., are also dominant in purification.
Because a scripture says,
â€œBecause of pleasure, the mind becomes concentrated,â€ and â€œFaith has suffering as its support,â€ and â€œOne should depart from joy, sorrow, and indifference.â€
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas transmit this opinion.
Other masters say that

the function of nourishing the body is not the activity of the eye, etc., but is the dominant influence of consciousness, because one is able to avoid danger only after having perceived it through consciousness, and because one receives material food.

The activity of seeing visible forms, etc., is also not separate from consciousness. Therefore the common activity of the eye faculty, etc., cannot be established as a separate dominant activity. Therefore the eye, etc., are not established as faculties because of this.
If this is so, how is it?
The verse says:
The six faculties are generally established as dominant in the perception of their own objects.
Two faculties are established from the body, the female and male faculties, which are dominant in sexual distinctions.
Because of the predominance in the defilement and purification of those who live together.
It should be known that the life faculty and the five feelings, faith and so forth, are established as faculties.
The faculties of the one who has not yet known, the one who knows, and the one who is fully endowed with knowledge are also like this.
They are predominant in attaining the subsequent paths, nirvana, and so forth.
The treatise says:
The six consciousnesses are called the faculties that perceive their own objects.

The five faculties such as the eye have a predominant function in the consciousness that perceives each separate object. The sixth mental faculty has a predominant function in the consciousness that perceives all objects. Therefore, the eye and the other six are each established as a faculty.
Shouldn't form and so forth also be established as faculties because they have a predominant function in the consciousness that perceives them?
Objects do not have a predominant function in consciousness.

The predominant function is called supreme and sovereign. The eye is called predominant because it is supreme and sovereign in the consciousness that perceives form. This is because it is the common cause for perceiving various forms, and because the consciousness follows the eye faculty in being clear or dim.
Form is not like this, because the two are mutually contradictory.
Up to the mental faculty and dharmas are also like this.
The female and male faculties are established again from the body, because they have dominance in the female and male natures.
The substance of the female and male faculties is not separate from the body faculty, because it is established with this name in one part of the body.

According to their order, in the female and male natures, these female and male faculties have a dominant function. This place is slightly different from other places of the body faculty, therefore they are established separately from the body faculty as two.
The differences in form, voice, activity, and inclination of the female body are called the female nature.
The differences in form, voice, activity, and inclination of the male body are called the male nature.

The differences in the two natures are due to the female and male faculties, therefore it is said that the female and male faculties have dominance over the two natures. In the abiding of the homogeneous collection, the life faculty has a dominant function. In defilement, the five feelings such as pleasure have a dominant function.
Why is this?
Because a scripture says:
because craving increases in pleasant feeling, anger increases in painful feeling, and ignorance increases in neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.
The five faculties such as faith have a dominant influence in the pure path.
Why is this?
Because by their power one subdues the defilements and attracts the noble path.

The phrase one should know encourages the understanding that each of these faculties can individually serve as a root. The three pure faculties have a dominant influence in attaining the subsequent paths, nirvÄá¹‡a, etc.

translated: The phrase it is also so illustrates that each of these faculties can individually serve as a root. That is to say, the faculty of I shall come to know the unknown has a dominant influence in attaining the path of knowing (i.e., the second of the four noble paths). The faculty of knowing has a dominant influence in attaining the path of complete knowing (i.e., the third of the four noble paths). The faculty of complete knowing has a dominant influence in attaining nirvÄá¹‡a, because one who has not yet liberated the mind is unable to attain nirvÄá¹‡a.
The word etc. is used to illustrate another aspect.
What is this other aspect?

That is, the faculty of one who is still learning has predominance in the cessation of the passions that are eliminated by the path of insight. The faculty of one who has finished learning has predominance in the cessation of the passions that are eliminated by the path of cultivation. The faculty of one beyond training has predominance in the enjoyment of the pleasures of dhyÄna and concentration, because one experiences the bliss of liberation by means of this faculty.

If predominance is the criterion for being a faculty, then such things as ignorance should be established as faculties, because the causes of such things as ignorance have a predominance over such things as the karmic forces.

Also, such things as the vocal organ should be established as faculties, because the vocal organ, hands, feet, anus, and sexual organs have predominance, respectively, in such activities as speaking, handling things, walking, defecating, and sexual intercourse.
Such things as the vocal organ should not be established as faculties, because the characteristics of the faculties are as we have described them.
A verse says,
The mind, its support, its differentiation, its abiding, its defilement,
Its equipment, and its purificationâ€”the faculties are established on the basis of these seven categories.
The treatise says,
The mindâ€™s support is the six sense bases beginning with the eye.
The six internal sense bases are the basis of sentient beings. Their differentiation is due to the male and female faculties. They are maintained for a period of time by the faculty of life.

They are defiled by the five faculties of feeling. They are the equipment for purity by the five faculties such as faith. They are purified by the last three faculties. Therefore, the matter of establishing faculties is completely finished.
Therefore, it is not necessary to establish ignorance, etc., and the organs of speech, etc., as faculties, because they do not have the dominant function in this matter.
There is another master who explains the characteristics of the faculties differently.
A verse says:ğŸ”½Or, the first fourteen are established as the basis of transmigration, birth, abiding, and enjoyment,
And so are the last three in the case of returning to extinction.
The commentary says:
The word â€œorâ€ indicates that this is the opinion of another master, who establishes twenty-two faculties in terms of transmigration and returning to extinction.
The basis of transmigration refers to the six faculties such as the eyes. Birth is due to the male and female faculties, because they are born from them.
Abiding is due to the faculty of life, because they abide in dependence on it.
The faculty of feeling is the cause of the five feelings, because they are the experience of that faculty.
On the basis of this, the first fourteen faculties are established.
In the stage of cessation, the last eight faculties are established because of the differences in the four meanings.

The support of cessation is the five faculties of faith, etc. The first causes birth in the three pure faculties, the second causes abiding in the three pure faculties, and the last causes the experience of the three pure faculties. The number of faculties is thus neither reduced nor increased.

For this reason, the order of the faculties is established in the scriptures. The voice should not be considered a faculty of speech, because speech is accomplished only through the differences of learning.

The hands and feet should not be established as separate faculties for grasping and traveling, because they are not of a different nature. That is, when the hands and feet are born in different places with different characteristics, they are called grasping and traveling.
Moreover, there is grasping and traveling apart from the hands and feet, as in the case of those who crawl on their bellies.
Therefore, the hands and feet cannot be established as faculties for grasping and traveling.
The anus should not be established as a faculty in the function of expelling, because heavy objects fall freely in space, and also because wind expels them.
The urethra should not be established as a faculty in the function of producing pleasure, because sexual pleasure arises from the male and female faculties.
Also, the throat, teeth, eyelids, and joints should be established as faculties, because they have power in swallowing, chewing, opening and closing, and bending and stretching.
Or, because all causes have power in producing their own effects, they should all be established as faculties. Although they have power, they are not dominant,
and therefore are not established as faculties. The same is true of speech, hands, feet, anus, and genitals. They are not dominant and therefore are not established as faculties.
Among these, the eye, etc., up to the male faculty have already been explained above.
The essence of the life faculty is not associated with the mind, and it will be extensively discussed in the section on the non-associated compositional factors.
The essence of faith, etc., is a mental factor, and it will also be extensively discussed in the section on mental factors.
The five feelings such as pleasure, and the three pure faculties, have no other place to be discussed, and therefore they should be explained now.
A verse says:
Bodily discomfort is called suffering, and this very comfort is called pleasure.
And the mental comfort of the third concentration is called joy in other places.
Mental discomfort is called sorrow, and there is no distinction between the two in the middle and neutral states.
The paths of seeing, cultivation, and no-more-learning are established based on the nine faculties, and three faculties are established.
The treatise says:
The body refers to bodily feelings, because they arise based on the body, and they are feelings associated with the five consciousnesses.
What is called discomfort has the meaning of harm. Among bodily feelings, that which can harm is called the faculty of suffering.
What is called comfort has the meaning of benefit. Among bodily feelings, that which can benefit is called the faculty of pleasure.

And the feelings associated with the mind of the third concentration that can benefit are also called the faculty of pleasure. In the third concentration, there are no bodily feelings, because the five consciousnesses are absent, and mental comfort is called pleasure.
This very mental comfort, excluding the third concentration, is called the faculty of joy in the lower three stages.
In the third trance state, mental pleasure is tranquil and still, because it is free from the craving of joy. Therefore it is called the faculty of pleasure.
In the three lower stages, mental pleasure is gross and agitated, because it is associated with the craving of joy. Therefore it is called the faculty of joy.
Mental pleasure associated with mental consciousness that injures and torments is called the faculty of sorrow.
The middle is neither pleasure nor displeasure, which is the feeling of neither sorrow nor joy. This feeling in the middle is called the faculty of indifference.
Is this faculty of indifference a bodily feeling or a mental feeling?
It should be said that it is both.
Why are these two feelings established as one faculty?
Because these feelings in body and mind are the same in being nondiscriminative.
Pain and pleasure in the mind are born from discrimination to a large degree, but this is not so for the body, because they are born in accordance with the power of the object.

They are also born in arhats and others, and therefore they are established as faculties in body and mind. Indifference is nondiscriminative and is born spontaneously, and for that reason it is established as one faculty in body and mind combined.

Moreover, the characteristics of pleasant and painful feeling are different in that the former benefits and the latter injures the body and mind. Therefore, they are established as separate faculties.

Neutral feeling is the same in the body and mind, is not associated with discrimination, and neither benefits nor injures. Its characteristics are not different. Therefore, it is established as a single faculty.
The mental faculty, pleasure, joy, and indifference, and the five faculties such as faith, these nine faculties are established as the three pure faculties in the three paths, respectively.

That is, in the path of insight, the nine faculties such as the mental faculty are established as the faculty of understanding that which has not been understood. In the path of cultivation, these same nine are established as the faculty of understanding. In the path of no-more-learning, these same nine are established as the faculty of perfect understanding.

On the basis of what are these three names established?ğŸ”½That is, in the path of insight, there is the activity of understanding that which has not been understood, and therefore it is said that it is called the faculty of understanding that which has not been understood.

In the path of cultivation, there is no more understanding of that which has not been understood, but one frequently understands that which has been understood in order to eliminate the remaining propensities. Therefore, it is said that it is called the faculty of understanding.
In the path of no-more-learning, one knows that one has already known, and is therefore called one who knows. One who possesses this knowledge is called one who is fully enlightened.

Or, one who has cultivated this knowledge and has already perfected one's nature is called one who is fully enlightened. That is to say, because one has attained the knowledge of extinction and the knowledge of non-arising, one truly knows for oneself:
I have fully known suffering and will not fully know it again.
And so on, at length.

Those faculties that they possess are called the faculty of knowing the unknown, etc. Thus the different natures of the faculties have been explained. Now we shall discuss the different categories of their meanings.
Among these twenty-two faculties, how many are contaminated and how many are uncontaminated?
Verse:
Only the last three are uncontaminated. The physical faculties, life, sorrow, and distress
Should be known as only contaminated. The remaining nine faculties are both.
Treatise:
The last three faculties mentioned above are only uncontaminated, which means they are free from defilements.
Defilements and contaminations have different names but the same substance.
The seven physical faculties, as well as life, sorrow, and distress, are exclusively contaminated.
The seven that are material are the five roots of eye, etc., and the two roots of femininity and masculinity, because they are categorized as the aggregate of form.
The mental faculty, the faculties of pleasure, sorrow, and contentedness, and the five beginning with faith are all pure and impure.
Other masters say
that the five faculties beginning with faith are only pure, because the World Honored One has said,
If one is completely lacking in these five faculties beginning with faith, I say that he is an outsider and belongs to the class of common worldlings.
This is not a valid proof, because these words refer to the pure faculties.
How do you know this?
Because these words are spoken after the distinctions among the holy classes have been established on the basis of the pure faculties beginning with faith.
Or, the class of common worldlings is of two kinds:
internal and external.
The internal are those who have not severed the good roots, and the external are those who have severed the good roots.
These words are spoken with reference to the external common worldlings.
If one is completely lacking in these five faculties beginning with faith, I say that he is an external common worldling.
Also, a scripture says,
There are sentient beings who dwell in the world, some born and some growing, with various distinctions of superior, middling, and inferior faculties.
This is because the Buddha had not yet turned the wheel of the Dharma at that time, so it is known that faith and so forth also pervade the contaminated.
Moreover, the World-Honored One said:

If I had not truly known the arising, cessation, taste, danger, and renunciation of these five faculties such as faith, I would not have been able to transcend this world of gods, humans, demons, BrahmÄ, and so forth, and would not have been able to realize supreme perfect enlightenment.
And so on, it is explained in detail.
Because it is not possible to contemplate the various categories of uncontaminated dharmas in this way, the five faculties such as faith pervade both the contaminated and uncontaminated.
Thus, the contaminated and uncontaminated have been explained.
Among the twenty-two faculties, how many are karmic results and how many are not karmic results?
A verse says:
Life is only a karmic result, and the last eight are not karmic results.
Form, mind, the other four feelings, each pervades both.
The treatise says:
Only the life faculty is definitely a ripening.
If this is so, then the many life forces that arhats retain are also life faculties. Whose ripening are they?
As the Abhidharma-Å›Ästra says:

distribute to the Saá¹…gha or to individuals the requisites for life such as robes and alms bowls, and after giving them make a vow, then enter the fourth formless concentration to the limit, and upon arising from concentration think and say:
May all the karma I have accumulated that would ripen as wealth be transformed and attract the ripening of longevity.
At that time, the karma that would ripen as wealth is all transformed and attracts the ripening of longevity.
There are also those who wish to lead and take the remaining ripening of past karma.
They say that the karma that was previously experienced has a remaining ripening, which is led and taken to be experienced by the power of the formless concentration practiced now.

At that time, the karma that could result in a long life is all transformed and attracts the result of wealth.

They arouse the power of the fourth formless concentration to the limit, attracting the great elements of the form realm to manifest in the body. A discussion arises from this discussion: What are the causes and conditions for the arhat to prolong his life?

It is for the sake of benefiting and bringing peace to others, or for the sake of the holy teachings remaining in the world for a long time. He observes that his own life is about to end, but he observes that others do not have these two abilities.
For what other reasons does he abandon his prolonged life?
The arhat observes that staying in the world would bring little benefit and peace to others, or that his own body is afflicted by illness and so forth.
As a verse says:
The pure practices are well established, and the noble path has been well cultivated.
When the life ends, one is joyful, just like getting rid of many illnesses.
You should know that in this case, based on what place, who is able to do this kind of abandoning of the life faculty?

It is said that men and women of the three continents, who are liberated not by time, who have attained the ultimate concentration, and who are arhats, because in their bodies there is mastery in concentration and no afflictions.
The sutra says:
The World-Honored One extends the life faculty and abandons the life faculty.
What is the difference between life and longevity?
Some say:
There is no difference.
As the Abhidharma treatise says:
What is the life faculty?
It is the longevity of the three realms.
Other masters say:
The results of past karma are called the life faculty, and the results of present karma are called the life faculty.
Some say:
By this, the continuity of the same type abides, which is called the life faculty. By this, one temporarily abides, which is called the life faculty.

The word many is to show the extending and abandoning of many moments of the life faculty, not a single moment of the life faculty. Because there is extending and abandoning of the life faculty and longevity.
Some say:
This statement is to refute the idea that there is a single real entity of life-force that endures for a long time.
Some say:
This statement is to show that there is no single real entity of life-force, but rather that these two terms life-force and life are provisionally established based on many activities.
If it were not so, it should not be said to be activities.
Why did the World-Honored One abandon many life-activities and retain many life-forces?
It is to show mastery over death that he abandoned many life-activities, and to show mastery over life that he retained many life-forces.
He retained only three months, neither increasing nor decreasing, because beyond this there would be no more to transform, and reducing this would not bring ultimate benefit to beings.
Moreover, it is to establish what he himself declared:
Because I have well cultivated the four bases of supernatural power, I can stay for one eon or more, as long as I wish.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas explain it like this:
It shows that he now subdues the two demons of the aggregates and death.
The World Honored One has already subdued the heavenly demons and the afflictions demons under the bodhi tree.
The incidental discussion is finished. The main discussion should be clarified.
The faculty of sorrow and the latter eight faculties such as faith are all not karmic results, because they are indeterminate. The rest are both.
The meaning is already established.
That is to say, the seven material faculties, the mind faculty, and the four faculties of feeling except for sorrow, each of the twelve are both kinds.
If the seven material faculties are nourished, they are not karmic results. The rest are all karmic results.
If the mind faculty and the four faculties of feeling are wholesome or defiled,

if they are the path of deportment, the path of craftsmanship, and the ability to transform, according to their respective circumstances, they are also not karmic results. The rest are all karmic results.
If it is said that the faculty of sorrow is not a karmic result, how can this sutra passage be understood?
As a sutra says:
There are three kinds of karma:

We have no disagreement with you, but the association of action with retribution is not correct. There is no escape from this difficulty.

Sorrow is not retribution, because sorrow is produced by discrimination and ceases through the absence of discrimination.
Retribution is not like this.
If you claim that the faculty of sorrow is retribution, then when one has committed a heinous crime and immediately experiences sorrow, the action should be called retribution.

Because those who are free from desire have no faculty of sorrow, it is not a ripened effect.
If this is so, then you should say that the faculty of pleasure, which is a ripened effect, exists for those who are free from desire.
What characteristics are there to show that it exists?

The characteristics of the existence of that are the same as the characteristics of this. That is, the faculty of pleasure is good, and it may exist in this state. The indeterminate ripened effect should be of the same type and not nonexistent.

Because sorrow does not exist in any way in this state, it is definitely not a ripened effect. The eight faculties of eye, etc., are good ripened effects in good destinies and bad ripened effects in bad destinies. The mental faculty is a ripened effect of both good and bad in either good or bad destinies. The faculties of pleasure, joy, and indifference are good ripened effects in any destiny. The faculty of suffering is a bad ripened effect in either good or bad destinies.
In the good destinies, those with two organs are only in the place of the organs. The form of the good destinies is attracted by unwholesome karma, because it is drawn by good karma.
Thus, this has been explained as the retribution, etc.
Among the twenty-two faculties, how many have retribution and how many do not have retribution?
Verse:
Sorrow definitely has retribution. The first eight and the last three do not.
The mind, the rest, faith, etc., each has both.
Treatise:

It should be known that the faculty of sorrow definitely has retribution. The verse says definitely based on the meaning of exception, meaning that it is shown that the faculty of sorrow only has retribution. Because it possesses both meanings, it is explained out of order.
The one who possesses both meanings is that sorrow is not indeterminate, because it arises from intense thought;
it is also not pure, because it is only on the level of distraction.
For this reason, it is explained out of order first, that the faculty of sorrow definitely has retribution.

The first eight, i.e., the five organs and the three feelings of pleasure, suffering, and mental pleasure, and the last three, i.e., the three pure faculties, definitely have no retribution, because the first eight are indeterminate and the last three are pure. The remaining seven have both kinds.

By implication, it is already established that the mental faculty and the five faculties of faith, etc., are of both kinds. The eleven faculties of the mental faculty, the five feelings, and the five pure faculties are of both kinds.

The mental faculty, the feeling of pleasure, and the feelings of mental pleasure and indifference, when wholesome or unwholesome and contaminated, have retribution. When indeterminate or pure, they have no retribution.
The faculty of suffering, when wholesome or unwholesome, has retribution. When indeterminate, it has no retribution.
The five faculties of faith, etc., when contaminated, have retribution. When uncontaminated, they have no retribution.
Thus we have explained those that have retribution, etc.
Among the twenty-two faculties, how many are wholesome, how many are unwholesome, and how many are indeterminate?
A verse says:
Only the last eight faculties are wholesome. Regret is wholesome or unwholesome.
The mental faculty and the other feelings are of three kinds. The first eight are only indeterminate.
The treatise says:
The eight faculties such as faith are exclusively good. Although they are listed later, they are mentioned first because they are the basis for the next.

The faculty of sorrow is only found in the categories of good and bad. The faculty of thought and the other faculties of sensation are found in all three categories. The eight faculties such as the eye are only indeterminate.
Thus we have explained the good, bad, etc.
How many of the twenty-two faculties are bound to the realm of desire, how many to the realm of form, and how many to the formless realm?
A verse says:
The realms of desire, form, and the formless, respectively, lack the last three,
And also the female and male faculties, sorrow and suffering, and in the formless realm, form, joy, and pleasure.
The treatise says:
The realm of desire lacks the last three pure faculties, because those three faculties are only unbound. It is understood that the realm of desire is bound to only nineteen faculties.

The realm of form, as before, lacks the three pure faculties, and also lacks the four faculties of male, female, sorrow, and suffering. It is understood that fifteen faculties are also bound to the realm of form.
Excluding the female and male faculties, because the form realm is already free from sexual desire and the female and male faculties make the body ugly.
If that is so, why is it said that they are male?
Where is it said?ğŸ”½In the sutras.
As a sutra says:
There is no possibility or condition for a female body to become Brahma, but there is a possibility and condition for a male body to become Brahma.
There is a separate male characteristic, namely what is possessed by a male body in the desire realm.
Those without the faculty of pain, because their bodies are pure and wonderful, and also because they have no unwholesome dharmas.
Those without the faculty of sorrow, because the continuity is moistened by shamatha, and also because they definitely have no harmful events.

The formless realm is like the previous, excluding the three pure faculties, the female and male faculties, sorrow and pain, and also excluding the five faculties of form, as well as the faculties of joy and pleasure. It should be understood that the remaining eight faculties are common to the formless realm, namely the mental faculty, the life faculty, the faculty of equanimity, and the five faculties beginning with faith.
This is how the faculties are bound to the desire realm, etc.
Among the twenty-two faculties, how many are to be eliminated by seeing, how many are to be eliminated by cultivation, and how many are not to be eliminated?
Verse:
The three faculties of mind, and the three feelings, are of three kinds. Sorrow is eliminated by seeing and cultivation.
Nine are to be eliminated only by cultivation. Five are to be eliminated by cultivation, three are not to be eliminated, and two are not determined.
Treatise:
The three faculties of mind, joy, pleasure, and equanimity are each of three kinds, because they are all eliminated by seeing, cultivation, and are not to be eliminated.
The faculty of sorrow is only eliminated by seeing and cultivation, because it is not pure.

The seven material faculties, life, and suffering are only to be eliminated by cultivation, because they are not defiled, because they are not born from the six [sense] faculties, and because they are all contaminated.
The five faculties such as faith are either to be eliminated by cultivation or not to be eliminated, because they are not defiled, and because they are all both contaminated and uncontaminated.
The last three faculties are only not to be eliminated, because they are all uncontaminated, and because dharmas without faults are not to be eliminated.
The distinctions of categories in various aspects have already been explained.
In which realm does one first obtain how many faculties with retribution?
A verse says:
In the desire realm, those born from wombs, eggs, or moisture first obtain two faculties.
Those born supernaturally obtain six, seven, or eight. In the form realm, only the faculty of life remains.
The treatise says:

Those born from wombs, eggs, or moisture in the desire realm first obtain only the two faculties of body and life at the moment of conception, because in these three kinds of birth the faculties gradually arise.
Why don't they obtain the two faculties of thought and indifference?
Because when they continue in rebirth, they are definitely defiled.
Those born supernaturally first obtain six, seven, or eight. Those without sex first obtain six faculties, like those at the beginning of the eon.
What are the six?
They are the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and life faculties.
If they have one sex, they first obtain seven faculties, like the gods and so on.
If they have two sexes, they first obtain eight faculties.
Can there be those with two sexes who are born supernaturally?
Evil destinies may have two sexes and be born supernaturally.
Having explained the initial obtaining of faculties in the desire realm,
Next, we will explain the form and formless realms.
In the desire realm, desire is predominant, so it is simply called desire. In the form realm, form is predominant, so it is simply called form.
The sutras also say:
The tranquil liberation transcends form and formlessness.
In the form realm, one first obtains six faculties with resultant nature, as explained for those born spontaneously without sex organs in the desire realm.
Only the life faculty in the higher realms means in the formless realm, because concentration is superior and rebirth is superior, the term higher is used.
In the formless realm, the first faculty with resultant nature that is obtained is only the life faculty, not any other.
Having explained the first obtainment of faculties with resultant nature,
in which realm does one lose how many faculties at death?
A verse says:
When dying, all faculties cease. In the formless realm, three. In the form realm, eight.
In the desire realm, either all nineteen or eight. In gradual death, four. In good rebirth, five increase.
The treatise says:
When about to die in the formless realm, the life faculty, mind faculty, and faculty of equanimity cease last.
If one is in the realm of form and is about to die, then the first three faculties, plus the five beginning with the eye, these eight are extinguished last.
Because all those born by transformation necessarily possess all faculties at birth and death.

If one dies suddenly in the realm of desire, then nineteen or eight faculties are extinguished last. This means that if one has two sexual organs, then ten faculties are extinguished last, namely, the two sexual organs plus the previous eight.
If one has only one sexual organ, then nine faculties are extinguished last, with the exclusion of one of the sexual organs.
If one has no sexual organs, then eight faculties are extinguished last, namely, the seven above plus the faculty of suffering.
The above discussion is based on sudden death.

If one dies gradually, then only four are abandoned last, namely, in the realm of desire, when one dies gradually, the body, life, mind, and indifference are extinguished last. These four are definitely not extinguished in any order.
The above discussion should be understood as applying only to those who die with defiled or indeterminate minds.

When one dies with a good mind in the three realms, the five faculties of faith, etc., must all be present. Therefore, in all the above-mentioned states, their number should be increased by the addition of the five faculties of faith, etc. That is, in the formless realm, they increase to eight faculties, and in the desire realm, they gradually increase to nine. The number in the intermediate states should be understood according to reason.
In the analysis of the faculties, all the dharmas of the faculties should be investigated. How many of the twenty-two faculties can attain the various fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a?
The verse says:
Nine faculties attain the two extreme fruits, seven, eight, or nine faculties attain the two middle fruits.
Eleven faculties are the basis for the arhat. This is said according to one interpretation.
The treatise says:
The two extreme fruits refer to the fruit of the stream-enterer and the fruit of arhatship, because they are the first and last of the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
The two middle fruits refer to the fruit of the once-returner and the fruit of non-returner, because these are observed between the first and last.

The first fruit of the stream-enterer is attained by nine faculties, namely the mind faculty, the faculty of equanimity, the five faculties such as faith, the faculty of subsequently knowing, and the faculty of knowing.

The faculty of having learned is in the path of immediate succession, and the faculty of having fully understood is in the path of liberation. These two assist each other in obtaining the first fruit.
In accordance with their order, they are able to be the cause of attraction and the cause of support for the acquisition of separation.

The fruit of arhatship is also obtained by nine faculties, namely, the mental faculty, the five beginning with faith, the faculty of having learned, the faculty of having fully understood, and one of the three faculties of pleasure, joy, and indifference.

The faculty of having learned is in the path of immediate succession, and the faculty of having fully understood is in the path of liberation. These two assist each other in obtaining the final fruit.
In accordance with their order, they are able to be the cause of attraction and the cause of support for the acquisition of separation.
The two intermediate fruits are obtained by seven, eight, and nine faculties, respectively, as is appropriate.
Why is this?

First, as for the fruit of once-returning, if it is realized in sequence, it is obtained by seven faculties if by the worldly path, namely, the mental faculty, the faculty of indifference, and the five faculties beginning with faith.
If one relies on the supramundane path, one attains it through eight faculties, namely the previous seven faculties and the faculty of final knowledge as the eighth.
If one is a person who transcends the fruit of nonreturner, then he obtains it by means of nine faculties, just as the fruit of stream-winner.

If one who is a person who gradually attains the fruit of nonreturner, he obtains it by means of seven faculties if he relies on the worldly path, and he obtains it by means of eight faculties if he relies on the supramundane path.
It is just as previously, one who gradually attains the fruit of once-returner.
If one who is a person who transcends the fruit of nonreturner, he obtains it by means of nine faculties, just as previously, one who transcends the fruit of once-returner.

Although this is the general explanation, there is a difference, because there is a difference in the stages on which it is based. Among the faculties of pleasure, joy, and indifference, one may take any one of them.
The previous fruit of once-returner has only the faculty of indifference.

Moreover, if one who is a person who gradually attains the fruit of nonreturner, if in the ninth path of liberation he enters the fundamental stage, he obtains it by means of eight faculties if he relies on the worldly path.
The uninterrupted path is associated with the feeling of indifference, and in the path of liberation there is also the feeling of joy. These two assist each other in attaining the third fruit.

In the acquisition of the disjunction from the bonds, the two causes are as explained above. By relying on the supramundane path, it is attained by nine faculties. Eight faculties are as explained above, and the ninth is the faculty of final knowledge, because it exists together with the uninterrupted path and the path of liberation.
Isn't it that the Abhidharma asks:
By how many faculties is arhatship attained?
The answer is:
By eleven faculties.
How can it be said that it is attained by nine faculties?
In reality, the fourth fruit is attained by only nine faculties.
But when the original treatise says eleven faculties, it is said on the basis of the possibility of their existence in one body.

This means that it is possible that a certain person, having repeatedly fallen away from the state of post-learner, again and again realizes the fruit of arhatship, with the feeling of pleasure, joy, or indifference present.

Because of this, the original treatise speaks of eleven faculties. However, the three feelings do not arise together at one time. Therefore, it is now said that it is definitely attained by nine faculties.
Why is it not said in the same way for the fruit of non-returner?
Because one who has attained the fruit of non-returner without the faculty of pleasure may later retrogress.
And one who has retrograded may attain it again through pleasure, but there is no meaning of retrogressing from the third fruit attained by skipping stages without first being detached.
Because this fruit of detachment is attained through the two paths, it is extremely firm.
Now we should consider: Which faculties are possessed?
How many faculties are definitely possessed among those faculties?
Verse:
One definitely possesses three: life, mind, and equanimity.
If one possesses the faculty of pleasure or body, one definitely possesses four.
If one possesses the eye faculty, etc., or joy, one definitely possesses five faculties.
If one possesses the faculty of pain, one definitely possesses seven.
If one possesses the female faculty, male faculty, or sorrow, or faith, etc., one definitely possesses eight.
Two pure faculties are eleven, the first pure faculty is thirteen.
Treatise:
If one definitely possesses one of the three faculties of life, thought, or equanimity, one definitely possesses all three. If any one of these three is lacking, one cannot possess them.
As for the remaining faculties, other than these three, the rest are all indefinite. That is to say, one may or may not possess them.

As for the four faculties of eye, ear, nose, and tongue, one definitely does not possess them if born in the formless realm. If born in the desire realm and not yet having obtained them or having already lost them, one also does not possess them.
As for the faculty of body, only those born in the formless realm definitely do not possess it.

As for the two faculties of female and male, one definitely does not possess them if born in the two upper realms. If born in the desire realm and not yet having obtained them or having already lost them, one also does not possess them.ğŸ”½As for the faculty of pleasure, ordinary beings born in the fourth concentration and the formless realm definitely do not possess it.
As for the faculty of joy, ordinary beings born in the third and fourth concentrations and the formless realm definitely do not possess it.
As for the faculty of pain, if born in the form or formless realms, one definitely does not possess it.
The faculty of sorrow is definitely not possessed by those who are free from craving for desire realm objects.
The five faculties of faith, etc., are definitely not possessed by those who have severed the wholesome roots.

The first pure faculty is definitely not possessed by all ordinary beings and those who have already attained the fruits.ğŸ”½The next pure faculty is definitely not possessed by all ordinary beings, those on the path of seeing, and those beyond training.
The last pure faculty is definitely not possessed by all ordinary beings and those still learning.
In states other than those prohibited, it should be understood that one definitely possesses the faculties as previously explained.
If one possesses the faculty of pleasure, one definitely possesses four, namely the faculties of life, mind, equanimity, and this faculty of pleasure.
If one possesses the faculty of body, one also definitely possesses four, namely the faculties of life, mind, equanimity, and this faculty of body.
If one possesses the faculty of eyes, one definitely possesses five, namely the faculties of life, mind, equanimity, body, and eyes.
The faculties of ears, nose, and tongue should be understood as also five, with the first four the same as for eyes, and the fifth being one's own faculty.
If one possesses the faculty of pleasure, one definitely possesses five faculties, namely, the faculties of life, mind, indifference, pleasure, and joy.

If one is born in the second trance state and has not yet attained the third trance state, one has abandoned the lower [trance state] but has not yet attained the higher [trance state]. What faculty of pleasure does one possess in this case?
It should be said that one possesses the defiled faculty of pleasure belonging to the third trance state, because one has not yet attained the other [faculties of pleasure].

If one possesses the faculty of suffering, one definitely possesses seven faculties, namely, body, life, mind, and the four feelings except for sorrow.ğŸ”½If one possesses the female faculty, one definitely possesses eight faculties, seven as explained for the faculty of suffering, and eighth the female faculty.
If one possesses the male faculty, one also definitely possesses eight faculties, seven as explained for the faculty of suffering, and eighth the male faculty.
If one possesses the faculty of sorrow, one also definitely possesses eight faculties, seven as explained for the faculty of suffering, and eighth the faculty of sorrow.
If one possesses faith and so on, one also possesses eight faculties, namely, the faculties of life, mind, indifference, and the five beginning with faith.

If one possesses the faculty of perfect knowledge, one definitely possesses eleven faculties, namely, the faculties of life, mind, pleasure, joy, and indifference, the five faculties such as faith, and the faculty of perfect knowledge.
If one possesses the faculty of knowing all that is unknown, one definitely possesses eleven faculties, ten faculties as above, and the faculty of knowing all that is unknown.

If one possesses the faculty of knowing all things, one definitely possesses thirteen faculties, namely, the faculties of body, life, mind, suffering, pleasure, joy, indifference, faith, etc., and the faculty of knowing all things.
How many faculties does one possess at a minimum?
A verse says:
At a minimum, eight without good, possessing the faculties of sensation, body, life, and mind.
Fools born in the formless realm possess the faculties of good, life, mind, and indifference.
The treatise says:
Those who have severed the roots of good are called those without good.
If they possess a minimum, they possess eight faculties, namely, the five faculties of sensation, and the faculties of body, life, and mind.
Sensation means that which can sense and receive, because it can receive and accept.
Or it is called sensation because it is by nature sensation, just as one who is perfectly complete is called perfectly complete.
Just as one who has severed the roots of good has a minimum of eight faculties, so too the fool who is born in the formless realm has eight faculties.
The fool refers to ordinary beings, because they have not yet seen the truth.
What are the eight?
They are the five faculties such as faith, the faculties of life, thought, and equanimity.
The five faculties such as faith are entirely wholesome, so they are collectively called good.
If that is so, then they should include the three pure faculties.
It is not so, because in this case it is based on eight faculties, and it is also said that fools are born in the formless realm.
How many faculties does one have at the maximum?
The verse says:
At the maximum, one has nineteen, excluding the three pure faculties of the two-sexed.
Holy ones who have not yet abandoned desire, excluding the two pure faculties and one sex.
The treatise says:
Those with two sexes are endowed with the faculties such as eyes, excluding the three pure faculties, and have the remaining nineteen.
Pure faculties are called pure because they are free from the two bonds.
Those with two sexes must be ordinary beings of the desire realm who have not yet abandoned desire, so they have nineteen.
Are there any that possess nineteen faculties?

Noble ones who have not yet abandoned desire also possess nineteen. That is, noble learners who have not yet abandoned desire and attachment possess the most, also possessing nineteen, excluding the two pure faculties and excluding one sex faculty.ğŸ”½If abiding in the path of seeing, excluding the faculty of knowing the unknown and the faculty of perfect knowledge.
If abiding in the path of cultivation, excluding the faculty of knowing and the faculty of perfect knowledge.
The two sex faculties, male and female, exclude one kind each, because noble ones have no two sex organs.
